text: hey guys it's Elise today I wanted to
have a little chat to you about fondant
because I get so many questions about it
I had one of my friends the other day
say she bought a packet and she just
didn't know where to start so I thought
you know what troubleshooting your
fondant I've showed you on my channel
how to make DIY fondant so your own
homemade marshmallow fondant which
tastes amazing it's really easy to make
I've also done a video on how to color
your fondant and some storage tips and
advice but my friend asked me if I could
do a video on going right back to basics
from when you very first get it out of
the packet so fondant is basically like
playdough and I know it scares a lot of
people often decorating it's seen as
like a professionals tool but really if
you can remember being three years old
and playing with play-doh you can work
with fondant and has so many uses these
are some examples of some different ways
that you can incorporate fondant you've
got things like large cakes wedding
cakes
you've got figurines there are so many
possibilities we've used that on
cupcakes you can stand it up and make it
firm or you can use it while it's soft
right back to basics when you first get
your fondant out of your package it
looks like this it's thought it doesn't
really look like anything terribly
special but it's not something that you
can work with straight away so whenever
you open the packet you need to knead
your fondant so just knead it between
your hands for about 2 or 3 minutes you
know the heat from your hands is going
to warm it up and it's going to soften
it down to that really nice play-doh
consistency as you're kneading it you're
also just helping it to get rid of any
cracks that are in the fondant so you
want to make sure that it's relatively
smooth and then you can roll it out
whenever you're rolling fondant you want
to apply just a sprinkle of corn flour
or a little bit of pure icing sugar to
your bench you can also apply a little
bit of that corn flour to your rolling
pin just to stop your rolling pin from
sticking to your fondant now people
often ask me if they can use something
else to roll out their fondant like
flour or sugar and things like that I
recommend either corn flour which is
also corn starch or pure icing sugar
plain flour is can it dry your fondant
out and it's going to make it crack and
any other substance like
Chris Cole or something like that is
going to change the texture of your
fondant so either cornstarch or pure
icing sugar is my recommendation and
they're the only two products that I use
so you can see there after a little bit
of kneading you've got like a really
nice sort of a pliable stretchy play-doh
the store-bought fondant because I
always get asked what it tastes like the
store-bought fondant is quite a bit
sweeter than the marshmallow fondant so
your DIY marshmallow fondant literally
tastes like marshmallows store-bought
fondant is really sweet but it's really
delicious and the idea with fondant is
you don't need a lot of it so I roll
mine out really really thin there's
nothing worse than a really thick chunky
coat of fondant on your cake so make
sure when you think about using it
you're only using it in small quantities
so that the eating of your cupcake is
just as nice as the presentation storing
your fondant like play-doh fondant dries
out when it's exposed to the air so you
need to store it properly I always wrap
my fondant in a little bit of plastic
wrap so I just wrap it in just a regular
bit of cling wrap and then I put it into
a ziplock bag this gives it a double
coat of protection from the air and it
allows it to last a lot longer if you're
working with like a marshmallow fondant
I recommend storing it in the fridge and
then bringing it out to room temperature
just before you go to work with it
that'll last you between 2 and 4 weeks
in the fridge store-bought fondant
however lasts about 12 months so I
normally put it in those ziplock bags
and a lot of the times they come in
these like funky buckets so I stick them
straight back in the buckets which also
helps to keep them airtight you never
want to refrigerate store-bought fondant
you always want to keep that at room
temperature moisture is the enemy
particularly of store-bought fondant but
of all fondant in most cases so if you
put moisture or water onto fondant it
actually starts to eat into it and to
break down the fondant the only time
that I recommend you use water with
fondant is when you actually want to
make the fondant glue something so a
tiny little dab of water on one section
of the fondant and less is more with the
amount of water you use allows you to
stick another piece of fondant straight
on top and acts like a little bit of a
glue it kind of makes the surface of the
fondant go a little bit sticky and then
the next piece just sticks on when that
sets it's really well stuck if you're
looking to have fondant decorations set
a little bit firmer and a little bit
faster than usual all fondant will dry
out so if I was to make for example one
of our little three dimensional
butterfly
that's going to take between 12 and 24
hours to completely dry it'll stand up
under its own weight and it's not going
to absorb the moisture from any
buttercream decorations that you might
stick onto it or stick it onto if you
want that to get nice and firm and set
in about six or so hours there's a
product on the market called either
Talos or CMC it's a white powder and you
add it to your fondant and it helps I
don't even know how but it helps your
fondant set really firm really fast and
by really fast I don't meant in five
minutes I mean in a few hours but it's a
few hours instead of a few days so if
you're planning on making one of my
fondant decorations or any fondant
decorations people often ask me how far
in advance they can make them I
recommend making your fondant
decorations a few days even a couple of
weeks in advance they're going to last
for the longest time so once they're set
you can get about six months out of a
fondant decoration make sure that you
store them in some sort of an airtight
container after they've set not before
they've set you need to let them set in
just the fresh air at room temperature
but once they're fully set you can pop
them into an airtight container just so
that you don't get any bugs or anything
gross on them if you're planning on
keeping them for an extended period of
time if you're gonna color fondant and I
have done a whole video on this which I
will link to down below but I always
recommend using a color paste or a
powder color you can use liquid
everybody thinks that you can't but you
can't it just will change the
consistency of the fondant a little bit
so it's actually going to make it a
little bit stickier and a little bit
harder to work with you can balance that
out by adding in just small amounts at a
time of that pure icing sugar you can
add regular icing sugar that's not so
pure but that does sort of start to dry
your fondant out a little bit it will
work but if you're covering something
like a massive cake as you're rolling
that fondant out it's going to dry it a
lot faster than just that straight
fondant whenever I'm making my own
decorations smaller things I love the
DIY fondant but if I'm ever covering
something like a massive wedding cake I
always go with a pre bought fondant for
some reason the elasticity of them is
better they roll out better and I seem
to get less cracking and less they call
it elephant skin where it all kind of
sags a little bit around the edges when
it comes to coloring fondant color
whatever color you like but for your
darker colors like your black your dark
green and your red just buy them pre
colored
you are going to need to add a ton of
food coloring to even come close to like
a dark gray or a reasonable color of
green or a darkish pink so I always
recommend they come in these little tubs
there's all different brands of them and
just get those three basic colors
already pre bought otherwise all of your
pastels all of your other shades of
colors I just have a tub of white in the
cupboard it lasts for 12 months and I
cut it off when I color it as I need to
once you've color that fondant it still
stores exactly the same as uncolored
fondant if you're trying to achieve a
sort of a darker shade without that
really black color I did some navy blue
the other day bear in mind that with
fondant and buttercream those colors
will develop a little bit overnight so
if you're looking for a darker shade of
blue don't just keep on adding food
coloring if your food colorings are not
making any difference set it aside let
it sit overnight and you'll probably
wake up in the morning to find that it's
kind of naturally darkened in color
anyway on that if you know you need to
add a fair bit of food coloring to the
fondant make sure your color at the day
before once again because we're adding
food coloring you are changing the
texture and because of all the kneading
required to get that food coloring
really well worked through that fondant
it's going to be a bit soft so let it
sit on the bench for 12 hours it'll firm
back up and it'll be a dream to work
with there's a ton of different brands
on the market for me it really doesn't
matter what you use I've use satin eyes
I've used big Kells I've used Wilton
I've used so many different brands and I
haven't come across one yet that I
really don't like working with but they
are all going to be a little bit
different and depending on your climate
is going to depend on which brand of
fondant works for you I'm in a pretty
humid environment so I like brands that
stand up a little bit more to the
humidity if you're in a really cold
environment you might want to softer
fondant because it's not going to be as
hard for you to knead when you first
take it out of that icy cold cupboard if
you are battling the humidity or
excessive moisture in the air you can
store your fondant decorations in a
cupboard just a kitchen cupboard with
one of those dehumidifier tubs that they
give you to keep the mold and mildew out
of like your cupboards and your
wardrobes it actually sucks the moisture
out of the air and it kind of creates a
little dry safe environment for your
fondant decorations particularly good if
you know there's some bad weather coming
that's just some of my hints and tips
for dealing with fondant so when you get
it don't be afraid to use it
they're really the key
you thing is just to give it a bit of a
need so that it's easy to work with and
make sure that your flour your surface
with that corn flour or with that pure
icing sugar so you're not getting a
sticky mess otherwise guys you are
working with sweet sugary play-doh
thanks very much for tuning into my
cupcake addiction
